trans-unit.source: Methods invoked within an application are called application-side methods. Methods invoked within <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> are called database-side routines.

seg-source.mrk: Methods invoked within an application are called application-side methods.
Methods invoked within <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> are called database-side routines.

target.mrk: Methods invoked within an application are called application-side methods.
Methods invoked within <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> are called database-side routines.

trans-unit.source: An application-side method can be exactly the same as a database-side routine. The only difference is where you invoke them. You write the method only once. Where you invoke the method--within the application or within an SQL statement--determines whether it is an "application-side" or a "database-side" method.

seg-source.mrk: An application-side method can be exactly the same as a database-side routine.
The only difference is where you invoke them.
You write the method only once.
Where you invoke the method--within the application or within an SQL statement--determines whether it is an "application-side" or a "database-side" method.

target.mrk: An application-side method can be exactly the same as a database-side routine.
The only difference is where you invoke them.
You write the method only once.
Where you invoke the method--within the application or within an SQL statement--determines whether it is an "application-side" or a "database-side" method.
